Pre-Game Insights: India has always had a strong cricketing reputation, but when it comes to facing New Zealand in ICC events, a feeling of unease engulfs Indian fans.
New Zealand has an 8-1 advantage over India in ICC events since the start of 1990, their only defeat coming at the 2003 World Cup.
Jasprit Bumrah and Mohammed Siraj will play crucial roles for India, while Matt Henry, Trent Boult, and Lockie Ferguson are poised to excel for New Zealand.
The batsmen have been prolific, with Rohit Sharma, Virat Kohli, and Devon Conway ranking high in the run charts.
The absence of Hardik Pandya due to injury leaves a critical gap to fill for India, and the pitch's pace and carry promise an exciting contest.
All eyes will be on young sensation Shubman Gill, who is on the cusp of reaching 2000 runs in ODIs.
Miscellaneous Highlights: The weather looks superb for the match, with temperatures ranging from 17° to 19°.
The pitch at the HPCA Stadium in Dharamshala is a bowler-friendly one, particularly favoring fast bowlers.
Dharamsala has been a venue where the fast bowlers have found some joy, and this has been the most bowling-friendly venue in this World Cup so far.
Tom Latham revealed that Dew had begun to form as early as 5PM in the days leading up to the game, so batting second might just continue to be an advantage.
Others: Rahul Dravid on Pandya's replacement: 'It's nice to have Ishan [Kishan] playing well, being a left hander. But Surya has [Suryakumar Yadav] also come into some form against Australia.'
Tom Latham sees mini matchups all through this fixture: 'India's top order has been fantastic this tournament. And again, our bowling attack has done a really good job up front as well.'
Trent Boult, New Zealand's pace attack has a left-arm edge to it, one that recent history would point to being a pain point for India's right-heavy top-order.
